Mentorship as a relationship Professional development aspects such as training and coaching are more transactional. This is because it happens in a specific duration with minimal or no follow-up. It does not maximumly recognize the uniqueness of the individual receiving the training or the coaching. Nonetheless, mentorship is a relationship between a mentor and a mentee. In this setting, the chemistry between the two is essential for success. When running mentorship programs, one ought to pay key attention to the relationship formed, as a mismatch may result in poor mentorship outcomes. More importantly, it is right for mentors and mentees to set clear expectations as they kickstart their relationship. In this relationship, the mentor's role is to pave the way forward for the mentee. The mentor needs to realize that the mentee has a unique journey, bearing in mind that what worked for the mentor may not necessarily work for the mentee. The mentor should allow the mentee to make their own decisions as they grow. This relationship should focus on the mentee‚Äôs development goals. It should be a future-facing bias. Another key aspect of mentorship relationships is that they should be voluntary and not paid for. With all these considerations, the mentee is the key driver of this relationship. #ELFImpact #Mentorship
